prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The CO snow lines for these 2 disks are predicted to be similar to that of TW Hya, around 30 AU (for LkCa 15, we expect it to be larger than the 50 AU cavity at least). we need at least 1-2 beams across the area for accurate size determination. So we request for a resolution of 0.3".
Requested sensitivity: We expect 4-5 beams across the N2H+ emission based on the previous SMA observations (DISCS, Oberg et al. 2010). In order to detect at least 0.7 Jy km/s flux with over 3sigma per beam signal, we request for an rms of 8 mJy/beam km/s or 9 mJy/beam at 0.15 km/s assuming the FWHM of the line is about 5 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator, it requires half an hour on each source with 3rd octile weather.
Correlator setup: Based on the inclination angles for all the disk sample, we need about 0.1-0.3 km/s spectral resolution, good enough to resolve the velocity structure and do further visibility analysis.
Besides the primary target line of N2H+ 3-2, for the other spectral windows available we propose to observe the emission of the DCN, DCO+ 4-3 and CH3OH line at 278.342GHz to explore the effects of the disk temperature structure on the midplane ionization, deuterium and organic chemistry.

The CO snow line for IM Lup is predicted to be similar to that of TW Hya, around 30 AU, we need at least 1-2 beams across the area for accurate size determination. So we request for a resolution of 0.3".
Requested sensitivity: We expect 5-8 beams across the N2H+ emission based on the previous SMA studies (DISCS, Oberg et al. 2011). In order to detect 1.59 Jy km/s flux with over 3sigma per beam signal, we request for an rms of 8 mJy/beam km/s or 10 mJy/beam at 0.15 km/s assuming the FWHM of the line is about 5 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator, it requires 20 minutes on source integation with 4rd octile weather.
Correlator setup: Based on the inclination 50deg, we need about 0.1-0.2 km/s spectral resolution, good enough to resolve the velocity structure and do further visibility analysis.
Besides the primary target line of N2H+ 3-2, for the other spectral windows available we propose to observe the emission of the DCN, DCO+ 4-3 and CH3OH line at 278.342 to explore the effects of the disk temperature structure on the midplane ionization, deuterium and organic chemistry.

The CO snow line for V4046 Sgr should be at least larger than the central cavity (29 AU, 0.8" in diameter). We need at least 1-2 beams accross the area for accurate size determination, so we request 0.5".
Requested sensitivity:
We expect 10 beams across the N2H+ emission based on the size of the CO disk from previous SMA observations (DISCS, Oberg et al. 2011). In order to detect the 2.58 Jy km/s flux with over 3sigma per beam signal, we request for an rms of 7 mJy/beam km/s or 9 mJy/beam at 0.15 km/s assuming the FWHM of the line is about 4 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator, it requires 22 minutes on source with 4th octile weather.
Correlator setup:
Based on the inclination angle of 33 degrees, we need about 0.1-0.3 km/s spectral resolution, good enough to resolve the velocity structure and do further visibility analysis.
Besides the primary target line of N2H+ 3-2, for the other spectral windows available we propose to observe the emission of the DCN, DCO+ 4-3 and CH3OH line at 278.342 to explore the effects of the disk temperature structure on the midplane ionization, deuterium and organic chemistry.

The CO snow line for AS 209 is predicted to be similar to that of TW Hya, around 30 AU, we need at least 1-2 beams across the area for accurate size determination. So we request for a resolution of 0.3".
Requested sensitivity: We expect 6 beams across the N2H+ emission based on the previous SMA observations (DISCS, Oberg et al. 2011). In order to detect 0.55 Jy km/s flux with over 3sigma per beam signal, we request for an rms of 5 mJy/beam km/s or 7 mJy/beam at 0.15 km/s assuming the FWHM of the line is about 4 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator, it requires 37 minutes on source integation with 4rd octile weather.
Correlator setup: Based on the inclination 38deg, we need about 0.1-0.3 km/s spectral resolution, good enough to resolve the velocity structure and do further visibility analysis.
Besides the primary target line of N2H+ 3-2, for the other spectral windows available we propose to observe the emission of the DCN, DCO+ 4-3 and CH3OH line at 278.342GHz to explore the effects of the disk temperature structure on the midplane ionization, deuterium and organic chemistry.

We expect the CO snow line for HD 163296 to be around 160 AU (Qi et al. 2011). We prefer 2-3 beams accross the area for accurate size determination, so we request a resolution of 0.9".
Requested sensitivity:
We expect 4 beams across the N2H+ emission based on previous SMA observations (Qi et al. 2013) In order to detect the 0.5 Jy km/s flux with over 3$\sigma$ per beam signal, we request for an rms of 7 mJy/beam km/s or 8 mJy/beam at 0.15 km/s assuming the FWHM of the line is about 5 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator, it requires 28 minutes on source with 4th octile weather.
Correlator setup:
Based on the inclination angle (45 deg), we need about 0.1-0.3 km/s spectral resolution, good enough to resolve the velocity structure and do further visibility analysis.
Besides the primary target line of N2H+ 3-2, for the other spectral windows available we propose to observe the emission of the DCN, DCO+ 4-3 and CH3OH line at 278.342GHz to explore the effects of the disk temperature structure on the midplane ionization, deuterium and organic chemistry.

The CO snow line for DM Tau is expected to at least larger than the cavity size of 19 AU, and we need at least 1-2 beams across the area for accurate size determination. So we request a resolution of 0.25".
Requested sensitivity:
We expect 5-6 beams across the N2H+ emission based on previous SMA observations (DISCS, Oberg et al. 2010). In order to detect the 0.97 Jy km/s flux with over 3sigma per beam signal, we request for an rms of 6 mJy/beam km/s or 7.5 mJy/beam at 0.15 km/s assuming the FWHM of the line is about 4 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator, it requires 33 minutes on source with 3rd octile weather.
Correlator setup:
Based on the inclination angle (45 deg), we need about 0.1-0.3 km/s spectral resolution, good enough to resolve the velocity structure and do further visibility analysis.
Besides the primary target line of N2H+ 3-2, for the other spectral windows available we propose to observe the emission of the DCN, DCO+ 4-3 and CH3OH line at 278.342GHz to explore the effects of the disk temperature structure on the midplane ionization, deuterium and organic chemistry.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Snow lines, or condensation fronts, of major volatiles in protoplanetary disks are proposed to regulate planet formation efficiencies as well as planet and planetesimal (comet) bulk compositions. Observational constraints on the location of major snow lines in disks are key to anchor models of planet formation, to constrain the origins of chemical and physical structures in our Solar System and in exo-planetary systems. Using ALMA Cycle 0 data, we recently demonstrated that high-spatial resolution observations of N2H+ emission enables direct imaging of the CO snow line location in protoplanetary disks. We propose to use this powerful chemical tool to survey the CO snow line radii in a diverse sample of disks, constraining how the CO snow line radii depends on disk characteristics, particularly the incident radiation field, and the existence and size of central cavity cleared by planets.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
